text: A look at the GOP's escalating pressure campaign against Google over Gmail's filters allegedly marking fundraising emails from right-wing candidates as spam
A look at the rise and fall of Bird, now a penny stock with a public market cap under $160M, as valuations in the scooter and bike rental sector collapse

“Today, a scooter rental ride hardly seems like a bargain. At typical rates, which include an upfront and per-minute fee, a 20-minute ride would cost about $6. That's more than a quick bus or subway ride.” VC-backed “micromobility” has crashed. https://news.crunchbase.com/ ...
when i think back on the 2010s economy, i'll picture a pile of unused scooters on a city sidewalk https://news.crunchbase.com/ ...
Unit economics analysis is most helpful if you use real numbers (eg, CAC and Gross Margin) and show your work. https://news.crunchbase.com/ ...

The 2010s saw the rise of many VC funded businesses that didn't make financial sense but the goal was for them to grow then exit to either a FAAMNG acquisition or IPO then leave the buyers as bag holders. Micromobility is a great example of this trend. https://news.crunchbase.com/ ...

to me the only way to explain the high prices of scooters and ebike “sharing” programs is to realize they're aimed at tourists. Cities will have to step in and treat them like a public utility if we want them to be affordable for the people who could most benefit https://twitter.com/...
Salesforce, whose logo appeared on Helium's website next to Lime's, also says it is not a Helium partner; Helium has removed both logos from its website
Lime and Salesforce logos disappear from Helium website
OK, let's talk about that big Helium story

Maybe there's a use for crypto after all? Uh, maybe not. @kevinroose wrote a glowing article about Helium in the NYT and never even bothered to check if Lime and Salesforce were actual Helium clients. Turns out neither of them were. https://mashable.com/...

that “old archive version” of Helium's website is from roughly 16 hours ago Helium removed mentions of Lime (and then Salesforce) from its website yesterday evening as a direct result of my reporting: https://mashable.com/... https://twitter.com/...

Another tough piece about Helium. This is an important lesson for any crypto/Web3 founders: If your project doesn't have any substantive purpose, nobody can claim that it's not living up to its goals. https://mashable.com/...

Crypto darling Helium lying about Lime and Salesforce using its network is hilarious. And A16Z, which just pumped another $50+m into it, surely knew. The danger here is a smart lawyer getting a class action suit for Helium hotspot users, who were misled. https://twitter.com/...

This is a good piece. Helium is a darling of the web3 paradigm, but it turns out that one key claim about its customers simply isn't true: Lime isn't a customer. And while the tech looks interesting, the coins are worthless and there's no return for the miners. https://twitter.com/...
brave to name your company after the main ingredient in a balloon https://www.theverge.com/...
something something hot air joke something something https://twitter.com/...
this is a great scoop, and also, befuddling that lime didn't bother saying anything as this company was hyped to regular people swept up in the web3 hype https://mashable.com/...
This is the number one company people point me to as a Web3 use case... https://mashable.com/...
Human rights groups say Facebook approved English and Swahili ads instigating ethnic violence in Kenya, after claiming to “ensure a safe and secure” election
Social Media Platforms Under Scrutiny Ahead of Kenyan Elections
Use “break glass” measures and suspend ads to protect Kenyan election, rights groups and Frances Haugen demand
Facebook faces suspension in Kenya over ethnic-based hate speech
Kenya's ethnic cohesion watchdog directs Facebook to stop the spread of hate speech on its site within seven days or face suspension, ahead of Kenya's elections
Facebook risks ban in Kenya for failing to stop hate speech

Facebook was informed it had approved pro-genocide ads in Kenya, so it took action by rushing out a press release describing all the ways it was cracking down on hate speech ahead of elections next month. Then it approved more pro-genocide ads. https://gizmodo.com/...

Facebook regularly suppress racial / ethnic/ gender minorities Those marginalized folks notice and report YEARS before these “exposés” ... no one who goes back and asks those marginalized folks what's happened seems to catch any respect The. It's a SCOOP Lather rinse repeat https://twitter.com/...
There is a clear need for oversight and consequences when Meta is encouraging genocide. There's no two ways about it. https://twitter.com/...
Facebook once didn't approve my ad for @DealsForGeeks because it had too much text. https://twitter.com/...
“Specifically, the groups said, Meta approved ads on Facebook in both Swahili and English that included calls to rape and behead Kenyan citizens along ethnic lines.” https://gizmodo.com/...
I'm going to keep saying this: there is no economic value to Facebook above $0. Literally none. Imagine running a company and having a “pro-genocide” problem. https://gizmodo.com/...
Tell me again about how Facebook is a powerful force for good, Nick Clegg? https://gizmodo.com/...

The Kenyan regulator has given Facebook one week to remediate the approval of ads advocating for ethnic cleansing > Facebook's reply? ‘People and machines make mistakes’ > looks instead the company has not invested the resources or is simply incapable ↘️ https://gizmodo.com/...

Platforms must be subjected to maximum scrutiny and transparency in contexts like this. But no matter how perfect human/automated/algorithmic moderation may be, there will always be errors at the intersection between “doing too much” and “not doing enough” https://gizmodo.com/...

And this is after the puzzling yet proud and incessant messaging from Meta and IG proper folks that the inability to lay out simple photos chronologically on a grid is beyond their capability. https://twitter.com/...
Facebook rejected one of my ads because the cover model had visible cleavage. https://twitter.com/...
From today's edition of What Horrible Thing Did FB Do Today? https://twitter.com/...

“It was good to see positive trajectory on our engagement trends this quarter coming from products like Reels and our investments in AI,” said Mark Zuckerberg, Meta founder and CEO. “We're putting increased energy and focus around our key company priorities .... ” - Q2 earnings https://twitter.com/...
And yet I was banned for life for making fun of Chuck Todd. True story. https://twitter.com/...

Facebook is an undeniable global hazard. What will it take to stop FB from promoting genocide and undermining elections in Kenya? “Facebook Approved Pro-Genocide Ads in Kenya After Claiming to Foster ‘Safe and Secure’ Elections” by @dellcam @FBoversight https://gizmodo.com/...

Last week, Facebook put out a press release touting how it has cracked down on harmful content in Kenya ahead of elections. Since then, it has approved pro-genocide ads, prompting a national watchdog to threaten to suspend it from the country. https://gizmodo.com/...

How many genocides is this corporation going to have to aid and abet before people start pulling the plug on their Facebook/Messenger/Instagram/ Meta accounts? Will it take bloody civil war and genocide in the US before users clue in and leave? https://twitter.com/...
The Rawandan genocide was egged on by a radio station (Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines) @facebook is truly evil. https://twitter.com/...
Serious question: How many genocides has Facebook been linked to around the world now? I've lost count, but anything more than zero seems ... not great. https://twitter.com/...
Indonesia blocks PayPal, Yahoo, Steam, Epic Games, Counter-Strike, Dota 2, and other websites for not complying with licensing rules introduced in November 2020
Indonesian Government Blocks Steam, Epic Games, PayPal, and Yahoo In The Country
Steam, Epic Games, PayPal, and More Digital Services Providers Banned in Indonesia
Indonesia bans access to Steam, Epic Games, PayPal, and more
Steam, Epic and other digital storefronts are currently banned in Indonesia
Indonesia blocks Steam, PayPal and other services over missed regulatory deadline
Indonesia has blocked Steam, Yahoo, PayPal, and more for license violations
Steam, Epic, PayPal And Battlenet Have Been Banned In Indonesia
A look at the supply chain resilience myth, as efforts to replicate the chipmaking process inside single countries or regions reveal and exacerbate bottlenecks

HIDDEN CHOKEPOINTS Bottlenecks in the chip #supplychain run as deep as the minerals needed for machinery parts. And China produces 60% of those minerals - an inconvenient truth for chip economies hoping to onshore. #CHIPSAct @NikkeiAsia Big Story: https://asia.nikkei.com/... https://twitter.com/...

Yes, the “chokepoints” are.much more complex than single companies in a particular country. Mess with supply chains at your own peril... The resilience myth: Fatal flaws in the push to secure chip supply chains - Nikkei Asia https://asia.nikkei.com/...

Big chip #supplychain review on why it's extremely difficult to onshore and build a complete #semiconductor ecosystem in a single country or region @NikkeiAsia exclusive & more extensive charts inside. Read here: https://asia.nikkei.com/...

A fascinating dive into the complexities of the chipmaking supply chain - and you learn that a COVID virus measures 100 nm. But there's a bias, no government seeks self-sufficiency, the policies aim at reducing vulnerabilities to leverage and disruptions. https://asia.nikkei.com/...
Chasing TikTok's success and leaving behind the protection of hard-to-replicate, large social graphs could end the lengthy dominance of platforms like Facebook
Elon Musk Files Response and Counterclaims to Twitter Lawsuit Over $44 Billion Deal
Social Media's Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Week

“TikTok's biggest legacy might be less about its current moment of world-conquering success, which will pass, & more about how, by forcing social-media giants like Facebook to chase its model, it will end up liberating the social Internet.” https://www.newyorker.com/... via @NewYorker

“TikTok, ...too, will eventually fade. The app's energetic embrace of shallowness makes it more likely, in the long term, to become the answer to a trivia question than a sustained cultural force.” https://www.newyorker.com/...

Excellent @NewYorker's article on social media competition. If you want to understand competitive dynamics in the digital space, you *have* to ‘get technical’. Full stop. Link: https://www.newyorker.com/... https://twitter.com/...

@kevinmarks Oh, for sure. But TikTok isn't even parasocial in the traditional sense. You often see content from people you don't follow. Stuff you might very much like, but that you aren't even driven to have a parasocial connection with.
@film_girl Facebook and especially Instagram have been more parasocial than social for a while now

Twitch has made massive strides for live-streaming content of all types, but YouTube is still the most consistent way for a creator to make money. That insulates that platform in a way I think few have recognized. And part of that consistency is that the feed isn't just algo

Although TikTok is dipping its toes into monetization, the fact that it is based on an algorithm rather than affinity subscriptions means that it isn't a consistent way to make money for all but the biggest creators/personalities. And longterm, I do think that will hurt them

I know Google is prioritizing Shorts on YouTube, which makes sense, but I hope the company doesn't make the same mistakes Meta is making with Facebook and Instagram, and leaning too far into it. Because the affinity/connection to the channel/personality is unbelievably powerful

What is so interesting is that for creators, the one consistent platform for actually making money over the years has been YouTube. Instagram Sponcon aside, if you want to reliably make money, YouTube remains the best option.

It's for this reason — that putting aside TikTok's recent dominance in terms of watch times — I think YouTube has never had any *real* competition in the non-live space and probably never will. It has the right mix.

I would argue that YouTube is the best hybrid of both models. YouTube doesn't rely on a social graph, but it does allow you to follow and have a relationship with certain channels or personalities AND you get recommendations.

This is excellent and is exactly what I've been arguing for several years on Rocket and other podcasts. The lack of a social graph on TikTok is what makes it viable in this world and Facebook moves away from that same social graph at its own peril https://www.newyorker.com/...

“The end of these legacy platforms.” Facebook has 1.98 billion daily active users. Instagram has 500 million. Doomed, no doubt. Users under 25, now spend up to 32 minutes a day on Instagram, while those >25 spend more than 24 minutes per day. https://www.newyorker.com/...

‘Pseudo-monopolies of this type, however, cannot last forever. The past decade has been good for these social-media giants, but the sudden ascent of TikTok might turn out to be the disruption that finally ends their reign.’ https://www.newyorker.com/...
Very, very good. Cal Newport on how Facebook, Instagram and Twitter simply can't do what TikTok does https://www.newyorker.com/...
“The past decade has been good for these social-media giants, but the sudden ascent of TikTok might turn out to be the disruption that finally ends their reign.” https://www.newyorker.com/...

“This rejection of the social-graph model has allowed TikTok to circumvent the barriers to entry that so effectively protected early social-media platforms like Facebook and Twitter.” https://www.newyorker.com/...

good piece, this by cal newport. tiktok and the fall of social media giants. “The past decade has been good for these social-media giants, but the sudden ascent of TikTok might turn out to be the disruption that finally ends their reign.” https://www.newyorker.com/...

TikTok and the Fall of the Social-Media Giants https://www.newyorker.com/... by Cal Newport via @NewYorker Interesting analysis: “...#TikTok can directly compete for users without the need to first painstakingly build up an underlying network, link by link.”

United States, Japan to launch new semiconductor research hub
Joint Statement of the U.S.-Japan Economic Policy Consultative Committee Strengthening Economic Security and the Rules-Based Order
U.S., Japan vow to defend int'l economic order, eye chip development
US, Japan set to agree on joint research for semiconductors - media

US-Japan economic 2+2, key points: 👉supply chain resilience 👉countering economic coercion 👉securing critical technologies/infrastructure 👉peace thru rules-based economic order U.S., Japan to defend open economic order amid China, Russia threats https://english.kyodonews.net/ ...

Important 🇯🇵🇺🇸 economic security development. Coincides with CHIPS bill clearing 🇺🇸House. $$s, scale means pooling of resources strategically critical, hence eventual project outreach to Taiwan, ROK. Japan, U.S. to launch R&D for 2-nm chip mass production https://asia.nikkei.com/...

How Modi's government is increasingly skirting India's own internet rules to crack down on free speech and dissent on social media, under a “fake news” pretext
WhatsApp and Twitter are pushing back against Indian government calls to yank content and weaken encryption, reports @mhbergen for @business. https://www.bloomberg.com/...
“We should consider it a canary in the coal mine for other faltering democracies.” https://www.bloomberg.com/...

“The government doesn't follow due process. The system is rotten to the core.” @tame_wildcard in excellent @mhbergen report on the stakes of the freedom of expression fight in India. https://www.bloomberg.com/...
New @BW: YouTube and social media's worsening quagmire in the world's largest democracy. “The system is rotten to the core.” https://www.bloomberg.com/...
Some streamers on Twitch, a more intimate platform than others, endure threats and stalkers and say Twitch gives limited support when dangerous situations arise
Amouranth Has Guns, Security Cameras, And A Guard Dog To Combat Stalkers

Famous Twitch stars like @Amouranth, @brookeab and @dizzykitten7 have dream jobs, making money streaming video games. But it comes at a price: endless harassment and obsessed fans who stalk them. “They feel like they know you.” New story w/@kashhill: https://www.nytimes.com/...

I'm just gonna keep sharing this, especially for the folks who told me I was overreacting when I had an active stalker on here and Twitch. That said I was just giving him attention & what he wanted. https://twitter.com/...

The laundry list of names, including myself, who have experienced terrifying stalker situations is staggering. This article gives a small look into a huge problem. Not only with lack of law enforcement protecting us - but the serious problem of parasocial interactions. 😞 https://twitter.com/...
“Stars on the video game streaming platform invite viewers into their homes virtually. What happens when one shows up in person?” https://www.nytimes.com/... https://twitter.com/...

After dealing with a stalker in 2018, @Amouranth/@wildkait got security cameras, guns and a guard dog. That didn't stop a fan from Estonia from showing up at her door. “I don't know what else to do at this point, besides build a moat with crocodiles.” https://www.nytimes.com/...

Harassment is common across social media, but livestreamers have it particularly bad. They have a warning for future stars: Be careful with your personal information. “Disguise your home. Don't do house tours. They'll find you,” @sweetanita said. https://www.nytimes.com/...

I have had a stalker since starting streaming. I was fortunate that police took me seriously. I am lucky to not recieve death threats or anything beyond the weird DMs daily. However we need to not normalize this behavior. It shouldn't come with the job. https://www.nytimes.com/...

I would encourage those to read the article also read the journal article that it references by @DrKowert and myself. This is not a problem specifically to the most popular streamers. You can have a stream of 8 or 8,000 viewers and still have these issues. https://twitter.com/...

“In April, after Ms. Bond, now 24, talked on Twitch about her plans to go to the Coachella music festival, online harassers threatened to kill her mother and set her house on fire if she went. She canceled the trip. Just in case.” https://www.nytimes.com/...

High-profile Twitch streamers are increasingly dealing with harassment and stalking from fans. “They see into your home, into your bedroom, and it feels very personal with them,” said one streamer who called the police after a fan tried to enter her home. https://www.nytimes.com/...

Sources: the Commerce Department told all US chipmaking equipment manufacturers to not supply gear to China for fabs that can make 14nm or more advanced chips

In the past two weeks or so, all US semiconductor equipment makers have received letters from Commerce telling them not to supply gear to China for manufacturing at 14nm or below. https://www.bloomberg.com/...
The US Secret Service says it is considering disabling iMessage on employees' phones, blaming the app's E2E encryption for the loss of deleted January 6 texts
Secret Service's ‘ludicrous’ deletion of Jan. 6 phone data baffles experts
If the Secret Service bans end-to-end encrypted messages, phone networks would be able to snoop on SMS texts
Secret Service considers disabling iMessage over missing Jan 6. texts
U.S. Secret Service blames iMessage for lost texts during January 6 insurrection
iMessage encryption was one reason why Secret Service lost January 6 texts, may prevent employees from using iMessage in future

This article is further confirmation of what I've also heard from trusted sources (and had been assuming): that the missing Secret Service messages were unarchived iMessage texts sent on agency-issued iPhones. https://www.washingtonpost.com/ ...

New: @SecretService is exploring disabling iMessages on employees' phones, spokesman tells me. iMessages are encrypted & can't be automatically retained through central platform. That may have contributed to loss of texts sought by Jan. 6 investigators. https://www.politico.com/...
The drum I've been beating for five years now is incompetence should have a randomizing effect on an outcome. If “incompetence” always benefits the same side, it's a strategy. https://twitter.com/...

it's true, you have to be incredibly incompetent to delete all texts relating to the most important day in your life as a Secret Service agent and then go into your cloud and delete the backup too. So much incompetency required. https://twitter.com/...

New: The Secret Service's “ludicrous” deletion of Jan. 6 phone data has baffled tech experts. The agency bungled a routine phone task by telling its agents to back up their own messages, which is “not something any other organization would ever do” https://www.washingtonpost.com/ ...
At least if the devices had iCloud backup turned on. Or if the user had another Apple device linked to the same Apple account.
@normative I believe those devices never backup to the cloud
Wait. If that's the issue, then even if the messages weren't captured by their internal backup system, they should still be recoverable from Apple by the device owner. https://twitter.com/...

NEW: What, exactly, would have to go wrong for the Secret Service to lose agents' Jan. 6 phone data entirely by accident in a system update? The expert consensus: A *lot* — unless the data retention system was set up to fail in the first place. Our story: https://www.washingtonpost.com/ ...
Insightful thread from a computer scientist and cryptographer, worth reading as a supplement to our story today: https://twitter.com/...

Two things to keep in mind: - these people never did the right thing while TFG was president, even when it was easy - this happened after a failed coup Simplest explanation: they destroyed evidence. A coup is sui generis. Requires a sui generis legal and political response. https://twitter.com/...

To add more context: there is not a single android phone from any manufacturer that can match the iPhone selfie camera in any environment that isn't perfect. Perfect lighting, Samsung's is better. Anything less than perfect and it goes to shit FAST https://twitter.com/...

Not so hot take: iPhones have the most reliable, best front facing camera hardware of literally any phone on the market. No matter where you are, what you film, or how the lighting is, the iPhone selfie camera will always have halfway decent photo/video.

OnePlus) and vivo stayed in the top five list. https://news.strategyanalytics.com/ ... @SA_Update https://twitter.com/...
